list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Prove that the sum of three consecutive positive integers is divisible
by $3$.
list.markScheme:
Let $n, \, n + 1$ and $n+2$ be three consecutive positive integers for
some $n \in \mathbb{Z^{+}}$.
The sum of the three integers is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{8em} n + (n + 1) + (n+2) &= 3n + 3 \\[6pt]
&= 3(n+1) \hspace{3em} [\text{multiple of $3$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the sum of three consecutive positive integers is divisible by
$3$.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Consider two consecutive positive integers, $k$ and $k+1$.
Show that the difference of their squares is equal to the sum of the two
integers.
list.markScheme:
The difference of the squares of $k$ and $k+1$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{9.5em}(k+1)^2 - k^2 &= k^2 + 2k + 1 - k^2 \\[6pt]
&= 2k + 1 \\[6pt]
&= k + (k + 1) \hspace{3em} [\text{sum of $k$ and $k+1$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the difference of the squares of two consecutive positive integers
is equal to their sum.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
The product of three consecutive integers is increased by the middle
integer.
Prove that the result is a perfect cube.
list.markScheme:
Let $n-1,\, n$ and $n+1$ be three consecutive integers for some
$n \in \mathbb{Z}$.
The product of these three integers is

$$
\begin{aligned}
(n-1) \times n \times (n + 1) &=  n \times (n^2 - 1) \\[6pt]
&= n^3 - n\end{aligned}
$$

If this product is
increased by the middle integer, $n$, then the result would be

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6.25em} (n^3 - n) + n &= n^3 \hspace{3em} [\text{perfect cube}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the result of increasing the product of three consecutive integers
by the middle integer is a perfect cube.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: - Show that $(2n-1)^3 + (2n+1)^3 = 16n^3+12n$ for $n \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3] - Hence, or otherwise, prove that the sum of the cubes of any two consecutive odd integers is divisible by four. [3]

list.title: Question 5
list.content: - Prove that $\dfrac{5}{x^2} = \dfrac{5}{x(x-2)}-\dfrac{10}{x^2(x-2)}$. [3] - Determine the set of numbers $x$ for which the proof in part (a) is valid. [2] $$ $$
list.markScheme:
- By working out the right side of the equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      \dfrac{5}{x(x-2)}-\dfrac{10}{x^2(x-2)} &= \dfrac{5x}{x^2(x-2)}-\dfrac{10}{x^2(x-2)} \\[9pt]
      &= \dfrac{5x-10}{x^2(x-2)} \\[9pt]
      &= \dfrac{5\ \cancel{(x-2)}}{x^2\ \cancel{(x-2)}} \\[9pt]
      &= \dfrac{5}{x^2}   .
  \end{align*}
  $$

- We cannot have a denominator equal to zero, and therefore

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      x^2 &\neq 0 \Rightarrow x \neq 0 \hspace{3.95em} \text{[from L.H.S.]} \\[8pt]
      x(x-2) &\neq 0 \Rightarrow x \neq 0 , 2 \hspace{3em} \text{[from R.H.S.]} \\[8pt]
      x^2(x-2) &\neq 0 \Rightarrow x \neq 0 , 2 \hspace{3em} \text{[from R.H.S.]}
  \end{align*}
  $$


Therefore the proof is valid for all values of $x$ except $x = 0$ and $x=2$.
$\answer{x \in \mathbb{R}, x \neq 0 \text{  and  } x\neq 2}$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Consider the function $f(x)=4x-x^2-1$. - Write $f(x)$ in the form $(x-h)^2+k$.[2] A line is drawn through the points $A(0, f(0))$ and $B(2, f(2))$. - - Write down the coordinates of points $A$ and $B$. - Find $g(x)$, the equation of the line passing through points $A$ and $B$. - Hence, show that the area enclosed by $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is $\dfrac{4}{3}$ units$^2$. [4] A horizontal line is drawn through the points $C(1, f(1))$ and $D(3, f(3))$. - Show that the area enclosed by $f(x)$ and line $CD$ is $\dfrac{4}{3}$ units$^2$.[2] Consider the two points $E(a, f(a))$ and $F(a+2, f(a+2))$. - Show that the area enclosed by the function $f$ and the line $EF$ is $\dfrac{4}{3}$ units$^2$.[5]

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Prove that if the sum of the digits of a 4-digit number is divisible by 3, then the four-digit number is also divisible by 3.
list.markScheme:
Let $n$ be a four-digit number such that

$$
\begin{align*}
    n=a_3a_2a_1a_0
\end{align*}
$$

where

$$
\begin{align*}
    a_3&=m \times 10^3\\
    a_2&=p\times10^2\\
    a_1&=r\times 10^1\\
    a_0&=s\times 10^0
\end{align*}
$$

$m,p,r,s\in\mathbb{Z^+}$ and $0 \leq m,p,r,s\leq9$ and $m\neq0$.
We can therefore rewrite $n$ as:

$$
\begin{align*}
n=m\times10^3+p\times10^2+r\times10^1+s\times10^0\tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{(M1)}}}
\end{align*}
$$

Because the sum of the digits is divisible by three, we know that

$$
\begin{align*}
    m+p+r+s=3k\hspace{1em}(k\in\mathbb{Z^+})
    \tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{(M1)}}}\\
\end{align*}
$$

We want to get that $3k$ into our equation for $n$ above as it is clearly divisible by 3, so we will rearrange to isolate for $s$:

$$
\begin{align*}
    s=3k-m-p-r
\end{align*}
$$

Substituting this into the equation for $n$:

$$
\begin{align*}
    n&=m\times10^3+p\times10^2+r\times10^1+3k-m-p-r
    \tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{(M1)}}}\\[6pt]
    n&=m\times10^3-m+p\times10^2-p+r\times10^1-r+3k\\[6pt]
    n&=m(1000-1)+p(100-1)+r(10-1)+3k\\[6pt]
    n&=999m+99p+9r+3k \tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{A1}}}\\[6pt]
    n&=3(333m+33p+3r+k)\tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{A1}}}\\[6pt]
    &\hspace{-0.5em}n \text{ is divisible by 3}\\[6pt]
\end{align*}
$$

Hence the four-digit number is also divisible by $3$.
